title.narrative: La Minga: Biodiversity use and conservation in Colombia's pacific coast
La Minga: Biodiversity use and conservation in Colombia's pacific coast

description.narrative:
Fondo Accion har till Sida ansökt för finansiering av 7 miljoner SEK för att kunna genomföra projektet ”La Minga” i Colombia under perioden 2018 – 2021.
Insatsen syftar till att förbättra försörjningsvillkoren genom att bygga och genomföra förvaltningsplaner för hållbar användning av naturresurser, kombinerat med strikta strategier för bevarande av den biologiska mångfalden i de tre regionala marinskyddsområdena som omfamnar kollektiva territorier för afro-colombianska samhällen längsmed stillahavskusten i Colombia, en region som historisk har påverkats av våld och problem relaterade till kriget så som avskogning och degradering, olagliga grödor, olaglig gruvdrift, förorenat vatten och fattigdom. La Minga kommer därför garantera att ansträngningar för att den biologiska mångfalden representerar biofysisk, ekonomisk, sociokulturell och politisk mångfald i Stillahavsregionen.
Fondo Accion kommer genomföra insatsen tillsammans med Conservation International Colombia.
Insatsens totala budget är 17 miljoner SEK, av vilka Sidas finansiering är 7 miljoner SEK och de resterande 10 miljoner SEK kommer ges från andra finansiella källor mestadels av regionala miljömyndigheter, nationella NGOs och andra Colombianska ministerier inom miljö och hållbar utveckling.

Fondo Accion has applied to Sida for funding of 7 million SEK to carry out the "La Minga" project in Colombia during the period 2018-2021.
The intervention aims at the improvement of livelihood conditions through the construction and implementation of management plans for the sustainable use of natural resources, combined with strict biodiversity conservation strategies for three regional marine protected areas that embrace collective territories of afro-colombian communities in the pacific region of Colombia, a region that has been historically affected by violence and the problems arising from the war such as deforestation and degradation, illicit crops, illegal mining, water pollution and poverty. Therefore, La Minga will guarantee that conservation efforts represent biophysical, economic, sociocultural and political diversity in the Pacific Region.
Fondo Accion will implement the intervention together with Conservation International Colombia.
The intervention’s total budget is 17 million SEK, out of which Sida’s funding is 7 million SEK and the remaining 10 million SEK will be contributed by other sources of financing mostly composed by Regional Environmental Authorities, National NGOs and the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development of Colombia.

The Minga is a mechanism designed to support the conservation and management of marine ecosystems located in the conservation mosaics of three Regional Protected Areas (RPAs) in the Pacific Coast of Colombia. This support will be addressed specifically for the purposes of conservation, management, and sustainable use of natural resources, in the framework of the three Management Plans for each protected area.
The above is to be achieved by the strengthening of stakeholders involved in the formulation and development of such Management Plans, which include National authorities, regional authorities and ethnic communities that live in these areas (Afro Colombian communities and indigenous peoples).
Afro Colombian Community Councils control the use and conservation of natural resources within their territories, among other governance functions. The three La Minga marine protected areas have basic co-management schemes between ethnic communities and regional environmental authorities, but there is a substantial need to strengthen some aspects of these interactions in order to achieve progress and performance.
Therefore, the main purpose of the Minga is to bring together the main social and institutional stakeholders, conservation strategies and management mechanisms for the sustainable use of natural resources that ensure proper conservation of these RPAs to guarantee that conservation efforts represent biophysical, economic, socio-cultural and political diversity in the Pacific Region

title.narrative: La Minga: Biodiversity use and conservation in Colombia's pacific coast
La Minga: Biodiversity use and conservation in Colombia's pacific coast

description.narrative:
During the 2nd year of La Minga contribution, Swedens support allowed the financial mechanism to begin processes towards the identification and design of the activities that will be carried out in order to comply with the regional protected areas management plans.
The contribution has received support and acknowledgement both from public national and regional institutions such as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development and the Regional Environmental Corporations, as well as from the ethnic authorities represented by the Afro-Colombian community councils.
During the first period of the contribution (April, 2019), the investment plan for years 2019 and 2020 was approved by the Executive Committee. Based on this, during the second period, Fondo Acción was able to proceed with the first calls to select the local operators that will be in charge of developing the different activities of La Minga.
Eight modules were defined and approved by the governing and decision-making bodies of La Minga (Technical and Executive Committees) in July 2019; the calls were assigned to organizations in charge of executing projects on responsible fishing, marine biodiversity conservation, recycling, ecotourism, community monitoring, and control and surveillance. Four organizations developed the projects in the Regional protected areas in Málaga Bay (Regional Natural Park La Sierpe and Regional Integrated Management District La Plata, located in the Valle del Cauca Department) and the remaining four in the Regional Integrated Management District Gulf of Tribugá-Cabo Corrientes, located in the Chocó Department.
During this 2nd period, La Minga's fundraising strategy was also designed and put into operation. This included actions focused on reaching possible donors, both for the endowment account as well as for the sinking account. Potential donors encompass international cooperation agencies, private sector, national and regional public institutions and family foundations. As a result of this strategy, additional funds were approved from the Colombian Presidential Cooperation Agency for approximately 75,000 USD that will be part of the sinking account of La Minga.
With the arrival of the COVID-19 pandemic in March in Colombia, there was a reduction in the intensity of field activities, which led to a slowdown in the rate of investment, compared to the previous year. Although most of the local organisations (7) made a great effort to maintain the activities led by members of the local communities and adjusted their work plans to the requirements of the national and local authorities, there was one organisation (Marviva) that was slower on this process and, therefore, the activities have been reprogrammed for the beginning of 2021.
This first phase of La Minga investments allowed Fondo Acción to recognize learnings and challenges for the implementation of the long-term financial mechanism. The main are: i) the executing agencies selection criteria defined in the ToRs, ii) the need to stablish a preparatory phase with potential local operators to allow clear and complete information, iii) the requirement to strengthen the capacities of local organisations on project formulation and iv) the necessity to fortify the coordination and communication with the environmental authorities to facilitate their involvement in La Minga.
